course.subject: ELEC
course.name: Signals and Systems
course.description: This is an introductory course for signal and system analysis. The course covers signal analysis tools including continuous- and discrete-time Fourier series and Fourier transform, and Laplace Transform; interactions between signals and linear time invariant (LTI) systems, and differential and difference equations as LTI systems, sampling theorem; and application examples in communication and control systems. MATLAB introduced as an integral part of this course.
course.prerequisites: MATH 2011 OR MATH 2023 OR MATH 2111 OR MATH 2350 OR MATH 2351 OR MATH 2352

reviews.author: 燒賣
reviews.comment_content:
Compulsory for elec major and is pre-requisite elec 3000-level courses.

Advance knowledge from ELEC 1200 but much more calculation.
Although calculation is more difficult, the tutorials can help solve most of the academic troubles for homework and exam
reviews.comment_teaching:
all are lecture video and class meet every week

Although all knowledge have to be learn by ourselves and may have some troubles, professor and tutor (Prof MY) are willing to solve your questions.

MUST ATTEND TUTORIALS !!
Tutorials helps a lot to connect all skills and knowledge form the start of semester to the last
(knowledge tested in midterm  will be kept using throughout the course)
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm 25 %
Final 40 %
Class Meet 10 % (best 7 of 11)
HW 10 %
Lab 10 %

reviews.comment_workload:
-HW: 3 in total. Theoretically just following tutorial and lecture notes is fine. But it is quite hardly to calculate

reviews.author: garbage
reviews.title: Prepare to learn a lot and build up foundations for signal processing and control engineering.
reviews.comment_content:
The content is a lot, the core concepts are CTFS, DTFS, CTFT, DTFT and Laplace Transform.
This is NOT A MATHS COURSE, it is more like a language course. The key is to understand the four tables about Fourier Transform and Laplace Transform and apply them when needed, which requires little mathematical skills and no memorization.
-----------------------------------------------------
Actually, the engineering math courses are not real math either, but it doesn't mean that they are meaningless. Some cheaters may say stuff like "MATH1014/2011 is totally useless, I would not use them in the future". That's ridiculous. The key point of engineering math courses and fundamental courses is to turn the real life problems into familiar models. You may say the integration techniques are useless because we have wolfram alpha to do all the work, but wolfram alpha cannot model all sorts of complicated practical problems. You need to know how the concepts are used in engineering problems. (e.g. orthogonality, which carries different but similar meanings in this course, math 1014, math 2111) I recommend you guys watch the youtube videos of 3blue1brown, those are really high-quality shit, no matter you study cs, engineering, maths or physics.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor WONG's teaching is clear but a bit boring. After the weekly lecture, you need to watch another lecture he posted by yourself and learn the materials.
Attending MY's tutorials is definitely a MUST. Reviewing before attending her tutorials is also a MUST.
reviews.comment_grading:
8% attendance (best 8 out of 11)
8% post-class exercise (best 8 out of 11, as long as you finish you would get at least 0.5%)
12% homework (x3)
8% lab (x4)
4% matlab quiz based on lab materials
24% midterm
40% final
I got 9s and 10s for the weekly exercise, attendance, homeworks, labs, quiz nearly full mark, 45/53 for midterm (mean: about 50%) and 56/64 (mean: about 50% as well) for final.
This leads to an A+.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is not low. The content of the course is not that easy to understand. Prepare to review weekly. However, if you do understand the materials of each week before the next week comes, you would find that you won't spend a lot of time reviewing for the midterm and final.

reviews.author: NoRealRoot
reviews.comment_content: The content is quite challenging, there are many concepts you need to understand. You may fall behind when you cannot catch up the lesson.
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching is ok. It is better to attend the tutorial because the TAs are nice. They may help you to clear your concept.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is also ok. You may get B or B- if you are near the mean..
reviews.comment_workload: I think the workload is quite heavy because this courses have a lot of concepts you need to understand. Therefore, you need to spend time and effort to clear the concept except you are smart and understand them quickly.

reviews.comment_teaching:
I personally think that Professor Wong is not good at teaching, but he is a kind person, he is happy to answer your questions.

TA MY is very good at explaining the principle, I suggest you attend her tutorial, it was very helpful for understanding the content of ELE2100.
reviews.comment_grading:
Although the professor is not good at teaching, he is using absolute grading instead of a curve. After all the exams, my results are very low, surprisingly low, a single-digit mark for each part, I thought I definitely got a C grade. However, the released grade is surprising me, I got B.

Therefore, don't be too afraid your mark is too low.
reviews.comment_workload:
HW is quite difficult, need some time to do it.

Lab: There is a total of 4 labs. There are pre-lab and lab. In the pre-lab, TA will teach you how to do the lab(Of course not exactly the same). The lab report will be released earlier before the lab session, you can see the question first. I suggest you spare some time before the lab session, then you can do it earlier, otherwise, you will not get enough time to finish the lab on that lab session. Unless you are very good at Matlab.

Attendance is a must. TA will take a photo of each lecture at the beginning and end.
And there are in-class quizzes and off-class quizzes. Because there is just one lecture in one week. You need to watch the video on canvas by yourself, and there is a quiz that you need to answer. Of course, you can choose not to watch, but the quiz you must answer.

To conclude, I think the workload depends on what grade do you want to get in this course.

Chang Man Yee's tutorials are a MUST. Her teachings are much better than those lecture videos.

Final 40 %

reviews.author: sgargaa
reviews.title: Tough
reviews.comment_content: The content had a lot of mathematics in it. Complex numbers, Fourier and Laplace analysis were the primary topics of the course.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor was very boring and monotonous. His pace was very slow as well. He luckily posted lecture videos on canvas, which helped in reviewing the lectures. The TA MY Chang, on the other hand, was great. Her tutorials were very important and I would suggest you attend them, for great revision.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is fine as it is absolute graded. 92% above is A+, 85% is A, 78% is A-. Below 40% is fail.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is high because the lectures and course material is very work intensive and requires a lot of practice. There are just 4 lab classes in the semester, where MATLAB is taught (easier than MATLAB in ELEC1200). Homework assignments can be very demanding.

reviews.author: 69verynice
reviews.title: Just learn the operation to answer the question
reviews.comment_content: Content is the same as in previous semesters. It is challenging, but as I said in the title, just learn the operation/step to answer the question if you are lost/have no interest in learning the theory. It is good enough to get you through all the labs, hw, and exams. Although prof said that this course is not a math course, I was applying the same strategy that I use in math courses here, and it works like a champ.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I barely pay any attention in lectures so I won't rate prof's teaching. I was having a hard time staying up in class, so yeah, you know what is coming :)
The TA, on the other hand, is excellent. MY can explain abstract concepts in human language. Try to attend all of her tutorials, as part of the tutorial notes are covered on Canvas. The covered part will be revealed during tutorial, so you have to write down the hidden part on your own.
reviews.comment_grading:
Score allocation and coursework in 2100 is always changing, so I am not sure how relevant it is when you take this course.
Complex Number Test 5% (60%, below mean)
MATLAB Test 5% (69%, slightly above mean)
Lab*4 12% (~85%, slightly below mean)
HW*6 18% (~75%, slightly below mean)
Midterm 25% (65/100, above mean)
Final 35% (~77/100, above upper quartile)
Grade is B+
The Canvas page is gone already so I cannot give the exact numbers for my score, mean and SD. Expect a mean of mid to high 50 for exams.
Fair grading. Given that my performance in coursework are not that good, but kinda nailed it in the exam, B+ is what I deserve.
reviews.comment_workload:
I didn't see this coming, but homework contributed most of the workload. Around 1 week is given for each assignment, and they are pretty challenging. It can take 2 to 3 days to finish them, including the time required to review notes. DO NOT DEADLINE FIGHT!!!
Labs have almost zero workload. There will be one prelab a week before the lab to walk you through the tasks in the lab. All the codes are basically given to you.
Exams questions are similar to homework, so be sure you are familiar with the 'workflow' of finishing the questions in homework, and you are good to go.

reviews.comment_workload:
Each piece of HW is published after a chapter is finished and you usually need to submit it within one week. Some of the questions in HW are unseen and quite challenging and you need to spend so much time and effort to complete the HW.

reviews.author: Peteeeeeee
reviews.title: A Good Course
reviews.comment_content:
ELEC2100 is about learning a set of languages (mathematics, English, and Matlab) and the practice of the use of a fundamental set of mathematical relationships to model engineering problems related to signal processing, communication, and control.

Topics include CT and DT signals, impulse and frequency response, CT/DT Fourier Series/Transform, sampling theorem, differential equation representation of system and Laplace Transform.

ELEC2100 requires understanding and you do not need to memorize anything as important math relations will all be provided in the exams.
reviews.comment_teaching:
All materials are released week by week.
2 lectures(ppt. with video) are included every week.
You need to study the material before going to classmeet.

-In Class(before midterm)-
1.Review of key video lecture concepts by instructor (20 mins)
2.Group-based exercise (20 mins). Students form groups of 4 to work on a small number of sample problems.
3.Review of example problems by instructor (10 mins).
4.Individual exercise(20 mins)

But in this semester, after the midterm, some students complain that the workload each week is too heavy and changes were made:
-In Class(after midterm)-
1.Group-based exercise (~30-40 mins)..
2.Review of key video lecture concepts while reviewing example problems by instructor (~30-40 mins).
3.You can take the individual exercise back home to finish it and submit it at the beginning of next classmeet.

MY is a really good tutor. Even if you do not study the online material, you can still get a good result if you go to the tutorial every week.

reviews.comment_workload:
Online self-check (not counted to final grade) is available every week.

4 Labs in total and they are not difficult if you do the prelab exercise.

Matlab Test at the end of semester.

2 classwork every week (1 individual and 1 group)
Questions for Individual and group are similar and they use the sample questions provided online as the group exercise so if you do the sample Qs, the classwork wouldn't be hard.

reviews.title: Useful course about fourier transform
reviews.comment_content: This is basically a math course, based on complex exponential and euler's formula. Topics include CT and DT signals, impulse and frequency response, CT/DT Fourier Series/Transform, sampling theorem, differential equation representation of system and Laplace Transform. This is not an easy course and requires understanding, but it will be useful in signal processing area.
reviews.comment_teaching: When I take this course, they have changed to so-call "Blended Learning", which all the lectures are online. The "lecture" you see on the timetable is actually a class meet which you are provided with exercises to do it there, and those are graded. The online lectures are a bit boring, but it will be difficult for you to understand the topics just by reading the powerpoint, luckily the video can be sped up so it souldn't be a big problem. The TA hosting the tutorials explain the topics pretty well. Even if you are so busy that you didn't watch the lecture video, you are still strongly recommended to attend the tutorials.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm 25 %
Final 35 %
Class Meet 15 % (choose the best 8 out of 11)
Online Quiz 10 % (choose the best 8 out of 11)
Lab 10 %
Matlab Test 5 %

The grading seems fine to me, the labs are easy if you did the pre-lab exercises or if you are familar with MATLAB. The MATLAB test is closed book and no computers allowed, and you will need to write some MATLAB codes. Midterm and final does not involve MATLAB.
For my case, I got around 80+% marks in most of the quizzes, class meets and labs, 11/12 in MATLAB test, 70.5/80 in midterm, 89.5/100 in final  -----> A+
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is a bit heavy, online quizzes every week before class meet, and the class meets are graded, but luckliy there are only in total 4 labs throughout the semester, so there won't be labs every week.

reviews.author: 严智宸
reviews.title: Signals and Systems
reviews.comment_content: Elec 2100 is an introductory course for signal and system analysis, covering a broad range of topics related to the analysis and processing of signals. The course covers important concepts such as continuous- and discrete-time Fourier series and Fourier transform, Laplace Transform, and interactions between signals and linear time-invariant systems. The course also delves into the application of these concepts in communication and control systems. Overall, the content of the course is well-structured and provides a solid foundation for further studies in this field.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching quality of elec 2100 is generally good. The course is taught by experienced professors who are knowledgeable and passionate about the subject matter. The lectures are well-organized, and the professors do a good job of explaining complex concepts in an understandable manner. The professors also make an effort to engage with students and encourage participation in class discussions. However, some students may find the pace of the course to be relatively fast, particularly if they are not familiar with the material.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading system for elec 2100 is fair and transparent. The course typically involves several assignments, quizzes, and exams throughout the semester, which are all graded fairly. The professors provide detailed feedback on assignments and exams, which helps students to understand their strengths and weaknesses. The grading criteria are clearly defined, which helps to avoid any confusion or misunderstandings.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload for elec 2100 is moderate to high. The course involves a lot of material to cover, and students are expected to keep up with the pace of the lectures. Additionally, the course requires students to use MATLAB, which can be time-consuming for those who are not familiar with the software. However, the workload is manageable as long as students stay on top of their assignments and study regularly.

reviews.author: SpaceMan
reviews.title: Sorry it should be ELEC 2400
reviews.comment_content:
It basically focuses on the circuits (AC and DC circuits) by using those lows, like Kirchhoff's Current Law and Kirchhoff's Voltage Law (and more).

It also has a lab teaching how to building the circuit with those components. (it is not hard if you follow the manual correctly) You need to demo in the class.
reviews.comment_teaching: The lecture is quite boring but you have to attend the tutorial since it covers almost all the things in the lecture note and gives you a clearer mind to understand it. (The tutor Ricky is good and nice, you can send Whatsapp to ask questions.)
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is ok although I didn't get the expected grade since I made some mistakes in the final exam.
reviews.comment_workload:
It has total 5 hws and each one contains about 8 questions.
Each lab has a circuit you need to build.  
1 mid-term and 1 final exam.
